problem.statementHtml: Find the eigenvectors of the matrix \[A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ -3 & -1 \end{bmatrix}\].
hints: Use the fact that eigenvectors are non-zero
problem.solutionHtml:
To find the eigenvectors of A, we first need to find its eigenvalues. Let λ be an eigenvalue of A.

  • Compute \[A - \lambda I = \begin{bmatrix} 2-\lambda & 1 \\ -3 & -1 -\lambda \end{bmatrix}\]. This matrix represents the null space of (A - λI).
  • Find the eigenvalues by solving \[\det(A - \lambda I) = 0\].
  • For each eigenvalue, find its corresponding eigenvector by solving \[(A-\lambda I)v=0\]. Normalize the eigenvectors to ensure they have length 1.
